bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence Reed, Blossom Reed, Houston Lazear, Peggy Lazear Briggs, Cornelia Knox Kean, Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, Albert E. Truby, J.F. Siler, Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas, and Albert G. Love, August 11, 1952

div1.p: Hench writes about the progress on the Camp Lazear memorial park and states that the park and remains of Building No. 1 are to be dedicated in September.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence Reed, Blossom Reed, Houston Lazear, Peggy Lazear Briggs, Cornelia Knox Kean, Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, Albert E. Truby, J.F. Siler, Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas, and Albert G. Love, August 11, 1952
div1.p:
As you know, I and others have been disturbed by certain errors concerning
Camp Lazear and Building No. 1 of the U. S. Army Yellow Fever Board, which
have appeared in Habana newspapers these past three or four years. Camp
Lazear is now being graded and made into a little park, thanks largely to
Dr. Andreu (Cuban Minister of Health), Dr. Pedro Nogueira of Marianao (Habana)
and other Cubans. On a wall being erected behind Building No. 1 will be
bronze medallions with profiles of Finlay, Delgado, Reed, Carroll, Lazear,
Agramonte and Wood; also bronze tablets listing the names of the volunteers
for the yellow fever experiments.

Presumably the park and the remains of Building No. 1 are to be “dedicated”
during a medical convention in Habana this September. I think it is either
the Inter-American Congress of Public Health, September 26 - October 1, or
perhaps it is the International Congress on Hygiene to be held in Habana
this September 1952. As this date approaches, I wanted to be sure that
the above mentioned newspaper errors would not be perpetuated. When I was
in Habana in January, Doctor Nogueira assured me that the misunderstandings
would be corrected. But to learn how things were going I wrote him on July
7 and 26. Having no answer, I cabled him last week and have just received
his letter of August 6.

His letter seems to me to be entirely satisfactory. I see no reason to put
further pressure upon him at this time. Nor do I think we need to ask any-
one else in Cuba to see him or others about this matter just now.

I will ask Senora Agramonte Rodriguez Leon and Senoritas Rojas and Cabrera
(Finca San Jose) to keep me informed as to how the Habana papers, etc., are
handling matters. If things do not proceed properly (or as Doctor Nogueira
and I hope they will) certain other contacts can be made and certain actions
taken before the dedication. But as I wrote before, Doctor Nogueira has
always kept faith with me so far, and I confidently expect him to keep faith
with us now.

In a recent letter to him I suggested discretely that it would be wonderful
if certain special persons could be present on the occasion of the dedica-
tion. In particular I had in mind General and Mrs. Reed, Mrs. Blossom Reed,
Mr. and Mrs. Houston Lazear, Mr. and Mrs. Briggs, General and Mrs. Truby,
Mr. Hanberry (volunteer); also official representatives of the Surgeon General,
the State Department and the American Medical Association. Wouldn't it be
wonderful also if Mrs. Kean and a representative of the Wood family could go?

I was inclined to think that Doctor Cooke was too feeble to go and that
Major Carroll's son, George, might not be sociable enough. (As I have told
some of you in confidence, he appears to be disgruntled, unfriendly and un-
cooperative, perhaps even a bit paranoidal; very unfortunate.) But on
second thought, I do not think it is proper for me to make the latter in-
ferences about Doctor Cooke and Mr. Carroll and I am writing further to
Doctor Nogueira.

Now I have no idea how much money (if any) the Cuban Government could afford
or would be permitted to set aside for the travelling expenses of such special
guests. Since they only allotted $25,000 for the Camp Lazear project, I
doubt if they will be able to allot enough to bring to Cuba more than a few
of those I mentioned. But please see the enclosed copy of Doctor Nogueira's
letter.

Perhaps some could afford to go at their own expense, if they were officially
invited. Perhaps the Surgeon-General's Office could “activate” Generals Reed
and Truby temporarily and send them at Army expense. If so, perhaps the
Cuban Government might be able to help at least some of the others. (But
again see Nogueira's letter, which is not very clear on this point.)

We must remember that so far no American contributions for the Camp Lazear
project have been made, or even requested, partly for reasons given in one
of my previous letters. So far the Cubans have done everything for this
Camp Lazear renovation and Americans nothing. Therefore I wish indeed that
we knew how to raise quickly some American funds so that the appropriate
American “guests” could go for the dedication and thus demonstrate publicly
their approval and join them in honoring Finlay and Delgado as they are
honoring our compatriots. (I wonder if the State Department has any funds
for such purposes?)

As I wrote you, there are at present no plans or funds to enclose Building No. 1
properly. But once Camp Lazear is set aside I do hope to help start a Cuban-
American fund raising campaign so that a permanent memorial and protection
can be erected. Perhaps those of us who are younger would prefer to attend
that dedication-of-the-future. But for those of us who are older, certainly
now is the time to re-visit Camp Lazear, even though the memorial is not as
elaborate as one might wish.

I shall ask Doctor Nogueira to clarify his point No. 6. Meanwhile, can you
tell me whether those of you closely concerned with Camp Lazear would be able
to go for the dedication (a) if the Cuban Government invited you and paid your
way; (b) if the Cuban Government invited you but did not pay your way, but
the American Army or State Department might; (c) if the Cuban Government in-
vited you but no funds were available. In other words, could you go at
your own expense, taking this as a personal vacation to Havana?

Please write me (care of my office at the Mayo Clinic). Your letters will be
forwarded to me at once, air mail, while I am in Mexico the next two weeks.
I will answer promptly (via hotel stenographer) and keep in close touch
with Doctor Nogueira also. I am writing about all of the above to the Surgeon
General.

Always sincerely yours,
P. S. Hench, M.D.
PSH:alc
P.S.: Doctor Nogueira speaks English satisfactorily but writes it rather
quaintly. For your interest and confidential information I enclose a copy
of his letter. Let me re-write, paraphrase and summarize his letter thus:
Copies sent to: General Reed, Blossom Reed, H. Lazear, Mrs. Briggs, Sra. Agramonte,
Truby, Mrs. Kean, Col. Siler, Gen. Love, Sta. Rojas, Surgeon General.
August 11, 1952
Page 3
(“Free interpretation” by P. S. Hench; at least this is my understanding.)
Dear Philip:
.........
1. You, Philip, know me, Pedro, well enough to know that (as far as I'm con-
cerned or can see to it?) the site of Camp Lazear will not be renamed, but
will always be known as “Camp Lazear,” and the designation - “Building
Number One” - will always be retained. I do not believe any one on the
Commission will oppose that intention; we have often discussed it. Rest
assured (or “be quiet, Philip”) that, if this had not been my understanding,
I would have resigned and would no longer be a member of the Commission
for the Preservation of the park and “Caseta Number 1.” I regret very
much the newspaper errors, but I am contacting those who have been
responsible so that the errors can be corrected. I hope that I can gradually
get the newspapers to call the camp and caseta by their correct names.
2. I do not believe that any other name for this place is required or will
be used in the future and this place is, and only should be called, Camp
Lazear.
..........
6. Your suggestion that Truby, Reed, Hanberry and the others whom you
mentioned should be brought here for the inauguration seems fine to me.
I am sure (?) that the (Cuban?) Government will find an opportunity to
arrange for this (Or does Doctor Nogueira mean that he hopes the American
Government could make it possible to arrange this? - P.S.H.).
Perhaps it would be prudent if you would write them, in the form of a
“personal question” to learn their attitude about this. (Who does he mean
by “them,” American governmental persons, or the survivors and relatives
of the yellow-fever group? Does he mean for me to sound out our government
or to sound out you who are closely associated with the work at Camp Lazear,
you to whom I am writing, to see whether you would be able or willing to
attend the dedication? I'm not quite sure which he means. - P.S.H.)
(continuing)...It would “elevate us” (do honor to us) and be an unforgotten
act if the American Embassy and the Army and Navy would send personal rep-
resentatives (“contribute with the personal”). My own ideas on these matters
will be formulated next week and you will be the first to know my ideas.
Then you can tell me what you think about them and add your own ideas.....
Pedro.
